channel.title: Bob's Digital Man Cave
channel.description: The place where, surrounded with cool toys, you play with the shell and a text editor to build stuff

item.title: Welcome to my digital man cave!
item.description:
I needed a way to save the little things I try out. Tada! My digital man cave is born.

There is no specific theme to this blog other than record what interests me, what I test, like and use. There will definitely be some ruby, because I love it and whatever else I end up using. It’ll be Mac OS X and Linux centric. There will be shell, code, software … the usual geek stuff really.

BTW, I liked the Bash and Dash article from Brett Terpstra (@ttscoff) because it was so simple and straightforward. While reading it, it automatically triggered a “Could I do this in ruby?” question. And it turns out, I can and it’s, as well, dead simple. Here’s my rdash ruby script that I copied to /usr/local/bin:

#!/usr/bin/env ruby

require "erb"
include ERB::Util

%x[open dash://#{u(ARGV.join(' '))}]

Now, when I’m in the terminal, I can just do rdash ruby:FileUtils mv to look up the documentation in Dash.

OK, granted, I usually don’t do this, and I didn’t feel a need to do it because Dash is a Ctrl-SPACE away with the global search shortcut I chose. I sometimes use the Alfred workflow that comes with Dash (in the lastest versions). I often use Ctrl-h in Sublime Text or Atom. This being said, the “Bash and Dash” article led me to try something new and I have one more way to interact with a tool I use almost every day.

Anyway, I digress. One idea leads to the next, one link leads to the rabbit hole and hours fly.

Welcome :)
